results.title: Rififi a Tokyo = Rififi in Tokyo
results.brief_description:
Following the success of Jules Dassin’s ‘Rififi’, producers decided to exploit the franchise. A number of caper dramas involving a complex robbery were produced in a variety of locations, including Japan. In this particular installment a gang of thieves is planning on taking hold of a single diamond stored in the vaults of a Japanese bank.

Credits: Producer, Jacques Bar ; director, Jacques Deray ; writers, Auguste Le Breton, Jose Giovanni, R. M. Arlaud ; photography, Tadashi Arakami ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Keiko Kishi, Barbara Lass, Karl-Heinz Boehm, Charles Vanel, Hideaki Suzuki, Michel Vitold.

results.title: Rififi = Du Rififi chez les hommes
results.creator_credit: Indusfilms, Prima Film, Societe Nouvelle Pathe Cinema, Rene G Vuattoux and Jules Dassin
results.brief_description: Rififi is a classic French noir film, an unforgettable crime movie, based on the novel `Du Rififi chez les hommes’, by Auguste Le Breton. American Jules Dassin directed “Rififi” in France, where he was working in exile after being blacklisted in Hollywood. “Rififi” is the tale of Tony, fresh out of prison and looking for his wife (who’s taken up with another man), seeking retribution. Tony is a man of few words but decisive action. He is seduced into joining his old gang for a risky job - a precious jewel robbery to take place in the dead of the night whilst all of Paris sleeps. Tony’s crew consist of old buddies, Jo (Carl Mohner) and Mario (Robert Manual) and an ace safecracker Cesar Le Millanais (played by Dassin himself under the pseudonym Perlo Vita). Characters are well written and are depicted three dimensionally. The band of thieves is shown to have meaningful relationships with the women in their life, and with each other. Thirty -three minutes of the film are devoted to the crime itself - a wordless, almost soundless scene that is the epitome of heist cinema. Dassin won Best Director at Cannes for “Rififi” in 1955. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Riff raff [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Parallax Pictures, Channel Four, Newvision Films, Sally Hibbin and Ken Loach
results.brief_description: Follows the fortunes (and misfortunes) of Stevie, a young labourer fresh out of jail. He soon finds work on a building site, converting an old hospital into luxury apartments. Stevie finds support and fellowship from his fellow workers, a melting pot of men from different parts of England. Conditions on the site are lousy, as well as unsafe, and with no help from the developers, Stevie along with his mates take matters into their own hands.

results.title: Riding your bicycle [Junior Road Safety Series Episode 6]
results.creator_credit: Kenneth S Cox Productions, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Malcolm Otton, Kenneth S. Cox and Alan Harkness
results.brief_description: Made in 1971, this training film from the Commonwealth Film Unit is particularly interesting due to the lack of helmets and lycra we see everywhere on the road in 2014. The film teaches people how to ride safely and to try and avoid accidents by showing some examples of cycling gone wrong. Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection.

results.title: Riding your bicycle
results.brief_description: Outlines safe bicycle riding practices for the 7-12 age group. Firm safety rules are established and demonstrated, stressing the need for continual alertness, consideration for other road users and obedience to road rules and signs.

results.title: Riding the tiger
results.brief_description: Riding the Tiger is a series examining the history of Indonesia since the struggle for independence in 1945. The series focuses on the military organisation of Indonesian society and on the consequences of colonial rule on Indonesian politics and culture.

results.title: Riding the Gale
results.creator_credit: Hugh Piper, Genni Batterham, Kim Batterham, Stormbringer Films and Independent Productions (AU)
results.brief_description: In 1978, Genni Batterham contracted Multiple Sclerosis. The battle with this debilitating illness changed the course of Genni’s life and that of her husband, Kim - both individually and as a partnership. This documentary is about Genni’s disability and how she and her husband confronted Multiple Sclerosis and the issues surrounding it.

results.title: Riding on air: the HM-2 Sidewall hovercraft
results.creator_credit: Southern Photographic Studios and Ken Blackman
results.brief_description: Shows research and development of the hovercraft as designers and engineers collaborate in creating an advanced model. Covers the evolution of the hovercraft in Britain. Commentary by Raymond Baxter.

results.title: Riding on air
results.creator_credit: Editorial Film Productions and Central Office of Information for Foreign Office and Colonial Office
results.brief_description: Britain’s bicycle manufacturing industry and the popularity of cycling in Britain. Forerunners of the modern bicycle; the manufacture of bicycles; and annual cross country cycle race and the International Cycle Rally. No other credits available.

results.title: Riding in cars with boys (Collector's Edition) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Grace Films, Julie Ansell, Sara Colleton, Laurence Mark, Richard Sakai and Penny Marshall
results.brief_description: Beverly is a 1960s teenager - bright, ambitious and fostering dreams of becoming a writer when she falls pregnant and marries her boyfriend, despite her ambivalence toward him. Feeling trapped in a dreary marriage to an unmotivated drunkard, Beverly seeks to improve her life by studying for a degree - a goal that she hopes will relieve the monotony of her life. Set over twenty years, the film follows Beverly’s mixed fortunes as she struggles with an unfulfilling marriage, thwarted dreams and demands of being a parent. Beverly faces her travails with her best friend Fay, also a teenage mother, with whom she shares many experiences. In the title role Barrymore expresses impish frustration (as opposed to unbridled rage) at the numerous calamities that befall her. With an eventful narrative about family - especially mothers and sons, fathers and daughters - the dramatic intentions of the film, littered with scenes which strive for poignancy, are undermined by the fostering of a lightweight comic tone. In the acting stakes the standouts are Brittany Murphy as Fay and James Woods as Beverly’s dad. Directed by Penny Marshall (Big, A League of their own) and based on the book and true-life experiences of Beverly Donofrio.
